awd_titl_txt: Toward Enabling the Detection of Compact Binary Coalescences and their Astrophysical Characterization with a Network of Second-Generation Gravitational-Wave Interferometers
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will support the development, testing, and subsequent implementation of a fast data analysis pipeline for searching gravitational-wave (GW) signals from compact binary coalescences (CBCs) in the data of Advanced LIGO (aLIGO) and other second-generation detectors. These detectors are expected to make the first direct observations of gravitational waves and herald the birth of GW astronomy by harnessing information on the distribution of the sources in the sky, distance, masses, and spins. These observations may also shed light on the nature of the host galaxies of CBCs. This project will also support work on aLIGO commissioning and instrumentation at the Hanford site, and the development of rapid detector characterization techniques and tools.  To catch a prompt electromagnetic or neutrino emission from a CBC it is critical that the duty factors of the GW detectors be high for sky localization, and detector characterization and background estimation be rapid so that robust GW alerts can be communicated to electromagnetic and neutrino observatories.

Rapid detector characterization will facilitate the publishing of gravitational-wave data to the public, with robust data quality flags in hand. This project will also engage the faculty of the Washington State University campuses in Pullman and Tri-Cities in education and outreach on gravitational-wave science. The latter campus caters to a large percentage of Hispanic and Native-American populations, both of which are under-represented, and offers a rare setting for integrating university education with cutting-edge research in gravitation being carried out at a nearby lab.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the work of Sukanta Bose, Fred Raab, and their students and postdoc in commissioning the LIGO detectors, improving their performance by characterizing them, and applying tools they developed to detect excess transient noise in order to improve data quality. They also refined methods for detecting gravitational wave signals from binaries involving black holes or neutron stars while discriminating against noise transients. 

In developing methods for searching black hole binaries they collaborated with several Numerical Relativists, as part of a project called the second Numerical INJection Analysis, or NINJA-2. Thilina Dayanga successfully defended his PhD dissertation on this research project. Shaon Ghosh obtained his PhD by improving the performance of searches for possible gravitational wave counterparts of short hard gamma-ray bursts. Szymon Steplewski got his Masters for his contribution to the commissioning of aLIGO. Ryan Magee obtained his Masters for developing the method for detecting excess noise that appears in the form of combs of frequencies, which hurt the sensitivity of LIGO’s search for continuous gravitational wave signals, e.g., from spinning neutron stars. Bernard Hall defended his undergraduate thesis on his work on developing a tool for characterizing the cause of certain types of noise transients in aLIGO detectors. Nairwita Mazumder did her postdoctoral work on developing a noise budget model for the seismic isolation system of aLIGO. Some of the work noted here contributed to aLIGO’s observation of gravitational waves from two binary black hole mergers, namely, GW150914 and GW151226.

Some of the gravitational wave search tools and detector characterization tools that Bose and his team developed or contributed to are made public as part of a LIGO Scientific Collaboration-wide effort. Bose incorporated material on gravitational wave physics in his graduate and undergraduate curriculum, labs or lectures in Washington State University. He also gave several public lectures in the US and abroad on the discovery of GW150914 and the future of gravitational wave astronomy.
